body_html:
@aselle Thank you for your reply. I know the python code just defines the operations. However, a control dependency does not work for an operation defined elsewhere. So this control dependency does not make sure the total_loss is computed with up-to-date variables. I mean there is a race condition.

The question has been answered on StackOverflow (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49421529/how-does-tf-control-dependencies-work-for-operations-defined-elsewhere/49455352?noredirect=1#comment85995693_49455352). Thank you very much.

@aselle Thank you for your reply. I know the python code just defines the operations. However, a control dependency does not work for an operation defined elsewhere. So this control dependency does not make sure the total_loss is computed with up-to-date variables. I mean there is a race condition.
The question has been answered on StackOverflow (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49421529/how-does-tf-control-dependencies-work-for-operations-defined-elsewhere/49455352?noredirect=1#comment85995693_49455352). Thank you very much.
body:
@aselle Thank you for your reply. I know the python code just defines the operations. However, a control dependency does not work for an operation defined elsewhere. So this control dependency does not make sure the total_loss is computed with up-to-date variables. I mean there is a race condition.

The question has been answered on StackOverflow (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49421529/how-does-tf-control-dependencies-work-for-operations-defined-elsewhere/49455352?noredirect=1#comment85995693_49455352). Thank you very much.
